study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the composting process of vegetable oil mill effluent sludge mixed with domestic waste and its impact on the formation of fulvic acids and compost maturity.
results_summary: The study found that different sludge-to-waste ratios affected microbiological activity and fulvic acid composition, with M1 showing enrichment in oxygen-containing compounds and M2 in nitrogen-containing compounds. PCA analysis revealed distinct groups of parameters governing degradation and restructuring of fulvic acids during composting.
population_specificity: Vegetable oil mill effluent sludge and domestic waste mixtures (M1 and M2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dietary vegetable oil supplementation (perilla oil vs. corn oil) on intestinal phospholipid fatty acid composition, mucosal integrity, and PGE(2) levels in rats treated with CPT-11.
results_summary: Perilla oil increased omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids, alpha-linolenic acid, EPA, and EPA/AA ratio while decreasing plasma PGE(2), but it did not sufficiently attenuate intestinal damage from CPT-11 treatment. Corn oil showed no significant protective effects.
population_specificity: Rats injected with CPT-11.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sunflower oil levels (3% or 6%) and roughage source (rice straw or urea-treated rice straw) on feed intake, nutrient digestibility, ruminal fermentation, milk yield, and milk composition in lactating dairy cows.
results_summary: Urea-treated rice straw (UTRS) improved feed intake, digestibility, ruminal fermentation, and milk yield compared to untreated rice straw. Sunflower oil at 3% increased dry matter intake, milk fat percentage, and milk yield compared to 6%, with no interaction effects between oil levels and roughage source.
population_specificity: Four crossbred (75% Holstein Friesian) lactating dairy cows with an average liveweight of 410 ± 25 kg and 18 ± 11 days in milk.
effective_dosage: 3% or 6% sunflower oil in the concentrate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the biodegradation of vegetable oil in freshwater sediments under different conditions (methanogenic vs. iron-reducing) and the protective role of iron compared to clay and calcium.
results_summary: Ferric hydroxide significantly increased the rate of methane production from canola oil, while calcium reduced biodegradation. Sediment toxicity initially increased but decreased over time as oil mineralization progressed, with no other amendments significantly reducing toxicity.
population_specificity: Freshwater sediments (environmental study, not human subjects).
study_duration: Toxicity measured within 5 days; biodegradation monitored over time (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if feeding late-pregnant ewes a soya bean oil supplement could reduce their susceptibility to fasting-induced hypocalcaemia by enhancing calcium absorption from the gastrointestinal tract.
results_summary: The study found that ewes treated with soya bean oil had significantly higher plasma calcium concentrations after fasting and an improved calcium absorption index compared to controls, though bone mobilisation did not differ between groups. The supplement effectively reduced hypocalcaemia risk in late-pregnant ewes.
population_specificity: Mature ewes pregnant with twins grazing at pasture.
effective_dosage: 25 ml soya bean oil twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of olive oil on the photodegradation of PCDD/Fs in contaminated sawmill soil under practical conditions, including sunlight irradiation and lower-grade olive oil.
results_summary: Blending contaminated soil with two doses of olive oil (20 + 20%) and exposing it to sunlight for four weeks reduced 2,3,7,8-chlorinated PCDD/Fs by 59% and WHO-TEQ by 48%. Photodegradation with a single dose was less efficient, suggesting periodic olive oil additions are needed for optimal degradation.
population_specificity: Contaminated sawmill soil
effective_dosage: 20% olive oil by weight, with an additional 20% added midway in one experiment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze contamination levels (e.g., PCBs, pesticides) in commercially available vegetable oil dietary supplements rich in n-3 fatty acids and compare them with historic samples to assess trends.
results_summary: The study found that vegetable oils contain shorter-chain n-3 fatty acids and were analyzed for contaminants, but the abstract does not specify the exact contamination levels or health impacts. The nutritional benefits of these oils were discussed in relation to contamination risks.
population_specificity: Commercially available vegetable oil dietary supplements (no specific human population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of using ferric chloride sludge from water treatment as a coagulant for treating vegetable oil refinery wastewater.
results_summary: The study found that ferric chloride sludge was highly effective in removing oil and grease, COD, and TSS from vegetable oil refinery wastewater, with removal efficiencies up to 99% for oil and grease and TSS, and 83% for COD. The sludge performed comparably to alum and ferric chloride at certain doses.
population_specificity: Vegetable oil refinery industry wastewater.
effective_dosage: 1100 mg SS l(-1) (optimum dose), 1300-1900 mg SS l(-1) (comparative doses), and 1000 mg SS l(-1) with 12.5 mg l(-1) fresh ferric chloride (combination dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a permeable barrier containing soybean oil could effectively remove nitrate from flowing groundwater.
results_summary: The soybean oil-coated sand barrier removed 39% of nitrate-N over 30 weeks, with high efficiency in the first 10 weeks but declining effectiveness by week 30. Nitrite levels remained low throughout the study.
population_specificity: Groundwater (aquifer model)
effective_dosage: Not specified (sand coated with soybean oil)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different supercritical alcohols (methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol, 1-butanol, and 1-octanol) in the transesterification of rapeseed oil and alkyl esterification of fatty acids for biodiesel production.
results_summary: The study found that in transesterification, longer alkyl chain alcohols required longer reaction times, while in alkyl esterification, alcohol type did not affect conversion rates. The choice of alcohol for biodiesel production should consider performance properties and economic factors.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study on chemical reactions).
effective_dosage: Not specified (chemical reaction conditions: 300 and 350 degrees C).

study_goal: To investigate whether rapeseed oil-based cheese reduces serum total and LDL cholesterol concentrations compared to milk-fat-based cheese in subjects with mildly to moderately elevated cholesterol.
results_summary: Rapeseed oil-based cheese reduced serum total cholesterol by 6.7% after 2 weeks and 5.0% after 4 weeks, and LDL cholesterol by 7.0% after 2 weeks and 6.4% after 4 weeks compared to milk-fat-based cheese.
population_specificity: Subjects with mildly to moderately elevated serum cholesterol concentration in Eastern Finland.
effective_dosage: 65 g of rapeseed oil-based cheese daily.
study_duration: Two 4-week intervention periods with a crossover design.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a vegetable oil sprinkling system (soybean and canola oil) in reducing dust in swine production facilities.
results_summary: The study found that a 5% oil-water emulsion applied at 7-8 g/pig/day reduced total dust by an average of 52%, with no significant difference between soybean and canola oil. No notable differences were observed in respirable dust, ammonia, carbon dioxide, temperature, or humidity between treatment and control rooms.
population_specificity: Swine finishing rooms in a production facility.
effective_dosage: 5% oil-water mixture applied at 7 g/pig/day (soybean oil) and 8 g/pig/day (canola oil), 12 times per day for 12 seconds each.
study_duration: Second-year experiment of a multi-year study (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the hypolipidemic and anti-atherosclerotic effects of plant stanol esters derived from vegetable oil, wood, or a mixture of both in apoE*3-Leiden transgenic mice.
results_summary: Vegetable oil-derived plant stanol esters significantly reduced plasma cholesterol levels (-46%) and atherosclerotic lesion area (91±13%), with similar efficacy observed for wood and mixed sources. The severity of lesions was also markedly reduced, shifting from fatty streaks to minimal foam cell accumulation.
population_specificity: Female apoE*3-Leiden transgenic mice (10 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of cutaneous soybean oil application on somatic growth and plasma fatty acid levels in enterally fed preterm newborns.
results_summary: Preterm infants treated with cutaneous soybean oil showed significantly better somatic growth compared to the control group, particularly in infants small for gestational age. Both groups exhibited changes in linoleic and arachidonic acid levels, but these did not fully explain the growth differences.
population_specificity: Preterm infants admitted to the nursery, including those small for gestational age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of vegetable oil enriched in oleic acid versus fish oil enriched in omega-3 fatty acids on platelet aggregation and eicosanoid production in human subjects.
results_summary: The study found that vegetable oil did not significantly influence platelet aggregation or the formation of lipoxygenase products, unlike fish oil which showed notable changes in fatty acid composition and eicosanoid production.
population_specificity: 20 male subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of sunflower oil supplementation on nutrient digestibility and blood parameters in feed of varying energy concentrations.
results_summary: Sunflower oil supplementation improved the digestibility of ether extract, crude fibre, and N-free extract, particularly in low-energy diets, and altered blood lipid fatty acid composition without affecting cholesterol levels.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal subjects given the context of feed studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a vegetable oil sterol-enriched fat spread on plasma lipid, lipoprotein, and apolipoprotein concentrations in hypercholesterolaemic patients.
results_summary: The fortified fat spread significantly reduced LDL-cholesterol by 10-15% with no changes in HDL cholesterol or triglycerides. The effect was consistent across patients with statin-treated familial hypercholesterolaemia and those with type IIa hyperlipoproteinaemia not on lipid-lowering therapy.
population_specificity: 30 patients with heterozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia on statins and 32 patients with type IIa primary hypercholesterolaemia (total cholesterol >6.5 mmol/l) not on lipid-lowering drugs.
effective_dosage: 25 g/day of fortified fat spread providing 2.5 g of plant sterols.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the developmental toxicity and safety of vegetable oil-derived stanol fatty acid esters in pregnant rats.
results_summary: The study found no compound-related toxicity, adverse reproductive effects, or significant developmental abnormalities in rats treated with vegetable oil-derived stanol esters, even at high doses. Minor body weight decreases in the high-dose group were attributed to poor absorption rather than toxicity.
population_specificity: Mated female HsdCpb:WU Wistar rats
effective_dosage: 0%, 1%, 2.5%, and 5% total stanols (equivalent to 0, 1.75, 4.38, and 8.76% plant stanol esters)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a diet high in alpha-linolenic acid (alpha-LA) from flaxseed oil could elevate EPA concentrations in tissues comparably to fish oil supplementation.
results_summary: The flaxseed oil diet significantly increased alpha-LA and EPA concentrations in plasma and neutrophil phospholipids. After fish oil supplementation, EPA levels remained higher in the flaxseed group, suggesting alpha-LA-rich oils can effectively elevate EPA in tissues.
population_specificity: 30 healthy male volunteers.
effective_dosage: Fish oil supplementation: 1.62 g EPA and 1.08 g DHA daily (triglyceride form).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of high-dose vitamin D supplementation in vegetable oil on serum amino acid levels in ultramarathon runners.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of vegetable oil itself, only mentioning its use as a vehicle for vitamin D administration.
population_specificity: Thirty-five male amateur ultramarathon runners.
effective_dosage: 150,000 IU vitamin D in vegetable oil, administered once 24 h before the run.
study_duration: Single dose administered 24 h before the run.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of diets supplemented with predominantly saturated or unsaturated vegetable oils on exercising horses, focusing on metabolic and physiological responses.
results_summary: The study found no significant adverse effects from either saturated or unsaturated vegetable oil supplementation. While some metabolic differences (e.g., cholesterol, triglycerides) were noted between the groups, overall, both diets were well-tolerated with no clear disadvantages of one over the other.
population_specificity: Eight Thoroughbred horses engaged in standardized treadmill exercise.
effective_dosage: Approximately 12% of digestible energy (DE) from the oil source for 10 months, then increased to 20% DE for an additional 6 months.
study_duration: 16 months total (10 months at lower dosage, 6 months at higher dosage).

study_goal: The abstract does not mention Vegetable Oil or its effects.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss Vegetable Oil or its effects.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients with vitamin D deficiency.
effective_dosage: Not mentioned (related to vitamin D, not Vegetable Oil).
study_duration: 12 weeks (related to vitamin D intervention, not Vegetable Oil).

study_goal: The study does not address Vegetable Oil; it focuses on vitamin D3 supplementation and early rehabilitation post-PLIF surgery.
results_summary: The study does not report any findings related to Vegetable Oil.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent posterior lumbar interbody fusion (PLIF) surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of high-dose vitamin D supplementation in vegetable oil on kynurenine pathway metabolites and tryptophan levels in runners after an ultramarathon.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of vegetable oil itself, only mentioning its use as a vehicle for vitamin D supplementation.
population_specificity: 35 amateur runners
effective_dosage: 150,000 IU vitamin D in vegetable oil, administered once 24 h before the run
study_duration: Single dose administered 24 h before the run

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the interrelations between dietary patterns (including vegetarian) and clinical/metabolic outcomes in bipolar disorder patients.
results_summary: The vegetarian dietary pattern was associated with reduced depression scores, better psychosocial functioning, improved quality of life, lower BMI, cholesterol, LDL, and diastolic blood pressure. Nuts consumption was also linked to a better metabolic profile.
population_specificity: 66 euthymic or mild depressive individuals with bipolar disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of vegetarian diets and their components in the incidence and progression of glaucoma.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that vegetarian diets, rich in antioxidant and anti-inflammatory components, may be beneficial for glaucoma, but this approach has not been well studied. No specific results are provided regarding efficacy or outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with glaucoma, particularly normal tension glaucoma, is implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation versus corn oil (vegetable oil) on albuminuria, blood pressure, pulse wave velocity, and inflammatory markers in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in urine albumin excretion reduction between the omega-3 and vegetable oil (corn oil) groups. However, the omega-3 group showed improvements in pulse wave velocity and triglyceride levels, while the vegetable oil group's effects were not highlighted beyond serving as a control.
population_specificity: Patients with CKD and urine albumin excretion ≥30 mg/g creatinine.
effective_dosage: Not specified for vegetable oil (corn oil), but omega-3 dosage was 3,666 mg/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a potassium-rich vegetarian diet, with or without a potassium supplement, could reduce joint pain in rheumatoid arthritis patients as an adjunct to standard care.
results_summary: The study found that a high potassium intake (5-7.5 g daily) via a vegetarian diet and supplement significantly reduced joint pain in rheumatoid arthritis patients, with the most improvement seen in the group combining both interventions. The intervention was safe and well-tolerated, with no serious adverse events.
population_specificity: 172 symptomatic rheumatoid arthritis patients with a median disease duration of 6.5 years.
effective_dosage: 5-7.5 g daily potassium intake (via diet and supplement in arm B).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining time-restricted feeding (TRF) with a Lacto-Ovo-Vegetarian (LOV) diet improves metabolic markers, liver health, and weight loss in overweight and obese patients with Metabolic Associated Fatty Liver Disease (MAFLD).
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in weight, BMI, waist circumference, liver enzymes (ALT, GGT), Fatty Liver Index, insulin levels, TNF-α, triglycerides, and HDL-C compared to the control group, suggesting that TRF with an LOV diet enhances metabolic and liver health in MAFLD patients.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese patients with MAFLD (n=42 completed the study).
effective_dosage: Time-restricted feeding (16/8 protocol) combined with a Lacto-Ovo-Vegetarian diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the association between dietary patterns, particularly a lacto-ovo-vegetarian diet, and osteosarcopenia in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that a lacto-ovo-vegetarian dietary pattern was inversely associated with osteosarcopenia, with the highest quartile showing a significant reduction in risk (OR = 0.64). Key contributors to this effect were vegetables, fresh milk, eggs, and dairy products.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged 60 and above in Northeast China.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary patterns assessed via food frequency questionnaire).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing evidence on the relationship between a vegetarian diet and metabolic dysfunction-associated fatty liver disease (MASLD).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, as it describes a planned scoping review to summarize current evidence on vegetarian diets and MASLD.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥16 years with or at risk of MASLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a vegetarian diet on acne, particularly its potential benefits compared to other dietary interventions.
results_summary: The study found that a plant-based diet can benefit individuals with acne, and avoiding dairy consumption was highlighted as one of the most effective dietary changes for reducing acne. The abstract suggests a link between dietary differences and acne incidence, with Western diets correlating with higher acne rates.
population_specificity: Individuals with acne vulgaris (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The study aimed to describe a case of subacute combined degeneration (SCD) caused by vitamin B12 deficiency and its neurological manifestations, including brain white matter abnormalities.
results_summary: The study found that a 36-year-old female with SCD exhibited brain white matter abnormalities, which improved after 6 months of treatment, normalizing serum vitamin B12 and homocysteine levels.
population_specificity: 36-year-old female with SCD due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the health, wellbeing, and behavioral implications of a flexitarian diet (including low-to-moderate red meat) versus a vegetarian diet (with plant-based meat alternatives) in young adults.
results_summary: Participants showed excellent adherence to both diets, with higher satisfaction in the flexitarian group. Both groups increased vegetable intake and reported improved eating experiences and satisfaction.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults (80 participants, grouped as household pairs).
effective_dosage: Flexitarian group: ~390g cooked red meat per week; Vegetarian group: 350-400g plant-based meat alternatives per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze correlations between endometrial cancer risk factors, including lifestyle and dietary habits, using machine learning.
results_summary: The study did not specifically report findings on vegetarian diet effects but focused on predicting progression-free and overall survival in endometrial cancer patients using various parameters.
population_specificity: Women with endometrial cancer who underwent radical surgical intervention at the Almazov center in Saint-Petersburg, Russia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of a vegetarian diet on a child with late-onset methylmalonic acidemia and homocysteinemia.
results_summary: The study found that a vegetarian diet exacerbated symptoms in a child with methylmalonic acidemia, leading to fatigue and attention deficit, but reintroducing meat and supplements improved clinical and laboratory outcomes.
population_specificity: A 9-year-old girl with late-onset combined methylmalonic acidemia and homocysteinemia.
effective_dosage: Vitamin B12, folic acid, betaine, and L-carnitine supplements (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness and safety of a light vegetarian diet (LVD) combined with Qingjiang Tiaochang Recipe (QJTCR) in improving functional constipation.
results_summary: The study found that LVD and QJTCR could effectively improve constipation, as measured by weekly complete spontaneous bowel movements and other secondary outcomes, though no detailed results were provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: 90 patients with functional constipation at the China-Japan Friendship Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine differences in plasma and urine metabolites, particularly those involved in fatty acid utilization, when switching from an omnivorous to a vegetarian diet.
results_summary: The study found significant changes in metabolites related to fatty acid metabolism, including increases in soy-derived compounds and decreases in metabolites of xanthine and histidine, suggesting improved fatty acid oxidation. Differences were also observed between European American and African American women in plasma acylcarnitine concentrations.
population_specificity: 38 European American and African American omnivorous females, matched by age (25.7 ± 5.3y) and BMI (22.4 ± 1.9 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a lacto-ovo-vegetarian diet on plasma lipidome in CAD patients and assess associations between plasma lipids and coronary atherosclerotic burden.
results_summary: The vegetarian diet increased beneficial triacylglycerols with long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acyls and decreased harmful lipids like saturated fatty acyls, phosphatidylcholines, and sphingomyelins compared to a meat diet. These changes were associated with reduced coronary atherosclerotic burden.
population_specificity: 31 CAD patients on standard medical therapy.
study_duration: Four-week intervention for each diet, separated by a four-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a vegetarian diet (VD) reduces cardiovascular risk factors, including oxidized LDL-C, and alters gut microbiota and plasma metabolites in patients with ischemic heart disease.
results_summary: The VD significantly reduced oxidized LDL-C, total cholesterol, LDL-C, and body weight compared to a meat diet (MD). It also altered gut microbiota composition and plasma metabolites, with baseline microbiota linked to the observed LDL-C reduction.
population_specificity: Patients with ischemic heart disease (n=27 completed the study).
effective_dosage: Individually designed isocaloric diet plans (specific amounts not detailed).
study_duration: 4-week intervention periods (with a 4-week washout between diets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a vegetarian diet combined with aerobic exercise on glycemic control and body composition.
results_summary: The study found that participants who adopted a vegetarian diet combined with aerobic exercise had significantly lower fasting plasma glucose and insulin levels, as well as improved body composition compared to preintervention participants. The meta-analysis showed consistent reductions in insulin resistance, fasting glucose, and body mass index.
population_specificity: Participants in comparative studies of pre- and post-vegetarian diet adoption combined with aerobic exercise interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a high-fibre vegetarian diet (HFV) and a Mediterranean diet (MED) on hunger-satiety perception, glucose homeostasis, and appetite-related hormone release in overweight/obese individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that the MED meal resulted in higher levels of GLP-1 and oxyntomodulin, better glucose control, and a delayed second GLP-1 peak compared to the HFV meal, though self-reported appetite scores did not differ significantly between the two diets.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese individuals with type 2 diabetes (12 subjects, male to female ratio = 7:5, mean age 63 ± 8.5 years).
study_duration: Two meal interventions with a 1-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a vegetarian diet (VD) on gut microbiome composition and short-chain fatty acid production compared to a Mediterranean diet (MD) in overweight individuals with low-to-moderate cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: The vegetarian diet significantly altered the abundance of specific gut bacteria genera (Anaerostipes, Streptococcus, Clostridium sensu stricto, and Odoribacter) and reduced propionic acid production (-28%). However, neither diet induced major changes in gut microbiome diversity at higher taxonomic ranks.
population_specificity: Overweight omnivores (16 females, 7 males) with low-to-moderate cardiovascular risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness and safety of a light vegetarian diet (LVD) in improving functional constipation (FC) symptoms, particularly in patients with gastrointestinal damp-heat syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that LVD, when combined with drug therapy, improved complete spontaneous bowel movements (CSBM) per week and other secondary outcomes like constipation-related symptom rating scale (CSS) and TCM syndrome scale (TCMSS). However, full results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 92 patients per subtype (total 184) with functional constipation, specifically gastrointestinal damp-heat syndrome, recruited in China-Japan Friendship Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 3-month lacto-ovo-vegetarian diet on circulating vitamin B12 levels in omnivorous subjects.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in vitamin B12 intake (51.2%) and circulating levels (6.2%), with changes in intake strongly correlated with changes in circulating levels. Subgroup analyses indicated greater reductions in younger, overweight, non-smoking, and hypercholesterolemic participants.
population_specificity: Fifty-four omnivorous subjects participating in the CARDIVEG study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of a lacto-vegetarian diet combined with physiotherapy on pain reduction and body composition in women with fibromyalgia.
results_summary: Group A (core stabilization exercises + lacto-vegetarian diet) showed significant pain reduction and improved body composition (increased muscle mass, decreased fat mass) compared to placebo and control groups. The diet-exercise combination was more effective than diet alone or no intervention.
population_specificity: Women with fibromyalgia experiencing low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 6-month vegetarian diet on muscle and plasma creatine, carnitine, and carnosine homeostasis in omnivorous women, comparing outcomes with and without supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that a vegetarian diet led to a decline in plasma and muscle creatine levels over 3 months, which was mitigated by creatine supplementation. Carnitine levels remained unaffected, while carnosine levels increased only in the supplemented group.
population_specificity: Forty omnivorous women, divided into control, vegetarian, and vegetarian with supplementation groups.
effective_dosage: 0.8-0.4 g/d β-alanine and 1 g/d creatine monohydrate for the supplemented group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a lacto-vegetarian diet versus a non-vegetarian diet on diabetes incidence and related metabolic markers in Indian communities with sedentary lifestyles.
results_summary: The study found that diabetes incidence was lower in the lacto-vegetarian group (1.7%) compared to the non-vegetarian group (5.3%), despite similar lipid profiles and BMI/WC. Fasting blood sugar (FBS) was positively correlated with LDL and VLDL and negatively correlated with HDL only in the lacto-vegetarian group, suggesting potential benefits of this diet for diabetes prevention.
population_specificity: Indian communities practicing sedentary lifestyles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a low-calorie lacto-ovo vegetarian diet (Vd) versus a low-calorie Mediterranean diet (MD) on body weight, cardiovascular risk factors, and other health markers in overweight omnivores with low-to-moderate cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: Both diets similarly reduced body weight, BMI, and fat mass, but Vd was more effective in lowering LDL cholesterol, while MD led to greater reductions in triglycerides. No significant differences were found in oxidative stress markers or inflammatory cytokines, except for interleukin-17, which improved only with MD.
population_specificity: Overweight omnivores with low-to-moderate cardiovascular risk (mean age: 51.1 years, 78% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of Marchiafava Bignami disease in a vegetarian woman and highlight the importance of considering nutritional habits in diagnosing acute neurological disorders.
results_summary: The study found that a young vegetarian woman developed Marchiafava Bignami disease after childbirth, which was successfully treated with parenteral steroids and vitamins. The researchers emphasize the need to consider this disease in non-alcoholic patients with acute motor and cognitive disturbances and to assess nutritional habits.
population_specificity: A young vegetarian woman accustomed to drinking high amounts of tea, three weeks post-childbirth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the short-term effects of a low-fat vegetarian diet on lipid profile and fasting glucose in non-vegetarian subjects from a Mediterranean population.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in total cholesterol, LDL-C, HDL-C, and triglycerides after a 15-day low-fat lacto-vegetarian diet. The decreases in total cholesterol and LDL-C were independent of weight loss, while the reduction in triglycerides was mediated by weight loss.
population_specificity: 159 volunteers (42 men and 117 women) from a Mediterranean population, previously non-vegetarian.
effective_dosage: A whole lacto-vegetarian diet low in fat (20%) was provided as a full daily menu.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a vegetarian calorie-restricted diet versus a Mediterranean calorie-restricted diet on cardiovascular risk factors in healthy subjects with low-to-medium cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results for the vegetarian diet alone, but it aimed to assess changes in weight, anthropometric variables, and cardiovascular biomarkers. The trial sought to determine if there were statistically significant differences between the two diets in reducing cardiovascular risk.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects with low-to-medium cardiovascular risk (overweight with at least one additional metabolic risk factor, not on medications).
effective_dosage: Three isocaloric sizes (1400, 1600, 1800 kcal/day) based on energy requirements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of changes in fatty acid composition of serum phospholipids in diet- and exercise-induced changes in metabolic clearance rate of glucose (MCR) in subjects with type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: The vegetarian diet led to increased linoleic acid (LA) in serum phospholipids, which correlated positively with improved MCR and negatively with reduced visceral fat. The insulin-sensitizing effect of the vegetarian diet may be linked to the increased proportion of LA.
population_specificity: Subjects with type 2 diabetes (n=74).
study_duration: 24 weeks (12 weeks of diet intervention followed by 12 weeks of diet combined with aerobic exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a lacto-vegetarian diet versus a standard mixed diet on clinical, hemodynamic, and metabolic parameters in coronary heart disease patients treated with beta-blockers.
results_summary: The vegetarian diet group showed more pronounced improvements in blood pressure, exercise tolerance, and lipid profiles (reduced total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and atherogenic coefficient, increased HDL cholesterol) compared to the standard diet group. The vegetarian diet also counteracted the hyperlipidemic effects of beta-blockers.
population_specificity: 42 patients with coronary heart disease post-myocardial infarction, treated with selective beta-adrenoblockers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a lacto-ovo vegetarian diet versus a standard antiatherogenic diet on cholesterol levels and atherogenic coefficient in patients with coronary heart disease.
results_summary: The vegetarian diet led to significant reductions in total cholesterol (16%), LDL cholesterol (18%), and atherogenic coefficient (31%), while the standard diet showed minimal changes. Hypotiazide combined with the vegetarian diet also resulted in slight improvements in cholesterol levels.
population_specificity: 84 patients with coronary heart disease, divided into two equal groups.
effective_dosage: Not specified for the diet; medications: athenolol (50 mg daily) and hypotiazide (25 mg daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term weight-loss efficacy of a standard omnivorous diet versus a lacto-ovo-vegetarian diet and assess the impact of assigned versus chosen diets on weight loss.
results_summary: At 18 months, both assigned diet groups (standard and vegetarian) showed greater weight loss (7.9-8.0%) compared to those who chose their diet (3.9-5.3%). No significant difference in weight loss was observed between the two diet types.
population_specificity: 176 sedentary, overweight adults (mean BMI 34.0 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a calorie-restricted, low-fat lactoovovegetarian diet (LOV-D) versus a standard calorie-restricted, low-fat omnivorous diet (STD-D) on weight, cholesterol, and other metabolic outcomes over 18 months, while also examining the role of personal dietary preference.
results_summary: The study found no significant interaction between dietary preference and treatment for any outcome. The LOV-D group showed a borderline significant decrease in LDL:HDL cholesterol, and participants in the Preference-No groups had significant reductions in triacylglycerols. Overall, all participants reduced total energy and fat intake, leading to weight loss.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults (86.9% women, 70.5% white).
study_duration: 12-month intervention followed by a 6-month maintenance phase (total 18 months).

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness and safety of a low-protein vegetarian diet supplemented with alpha-chetoanalogues in slowing CKD progression in type 1 diabetic patients awaiting pancreas-kidney transplantation.
results_summary: The diet showed potential in slowing CKD progression, with improved glycemic control in some patients, reduced proteinuria in others, and no significant adverse effects reported. Nutritional status remained stable, and creatinine clearance loss was modest.
population_specificity: Type 1 diabetic patients with irreversible chronic kidney disease awaiting pancreas-kidney transplantation (9 patients, median age 38 years).
effective_dosage: 0.6 g/kg/day of low-protein vegetarian diet supplemented with alpha-chetoanalogues.
study_duration: From November 1998 to April 2004 (variable follow-up, some patients followed until transplantation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential advantages of vegetarian diets in the treatment and prevention of type 2 diabetes and its complications.
results_summary: The study found that vegetarian diets, particularly those rich in whole grains, legumes, nuts, viscous fibers, soy proteins, and plant sterols, may improve glycemic control, reduce cardiovascular disease risk, and lower serum lipids. These components may also benefit renal health by reducing hyperfiltration and proteinuria in type 2 diabetes.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes or insulin resistance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a semivegetarian diet and vitamin supplementation could halt or improve symptomatic progression in a child with glutaric aciduria type I.
results_summary: The study found that a dietary regimen and vitamin supplementation halted and even improved the symptomatic progression of glutaric aciduria type I in a 23-month-old boy with macrocephaly and minimal neurologic manifestations.
population_specificity: A 23-month-old boy with glutaric aciduria type I and macrocephaly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an antiatherogenic vegetarian diet could correct impaired lipid metabolism in patients with coronary heart disease (CHD) receiving selective beta-adrenoblockers (beta-AB).
results_summary: The vegetarian diet significantly improved lipid profiles, reducing total cholesterol by 16%, increasing HDL cholesterol, and decreasing triglycerides and VLDL cholesterol by over 30%. It also enhanced blood pressure control and exercise tolerance compared to the control group on a mixed diet.
population_specificity: 67 patients with CHD receiving beta-AB therapy (42 in the vegetarian group, 25 in the control group).
interactions: The vegetarian diet counteracted the hyperlipidemic effect of the beta-AB atenolol.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a vegetarian diet on clinical, biochemical, lipid metabolism, and plasma hemostasis parameters in elderly patients with ischemic heart disease.
results_summary: The vegetarian diet promoted normalization of clinical and biochemical parameters, improved lipid metabolism, and corrected plasma hemostasis in elderly patients with ischemic heart disease. The diet was found to be a promising therapeutic approach for this population.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with ischemic heart disease (average age 72.3 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a vegetarian diet could be effective for treating atopic dermatitis and to identify potential immunological mechanisms behind its effects.
results_summary: After a two-month vegetarian diet intervention, patients showed significant improvement in dermatitis severity (measured by SCORAD index), reduced eosinophils and neutrophils, and decreased PGE2 production, though serum IgE levels remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Twenty adult patients with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of fasting followed by a vegetarian diet in treating rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Pooled data from controlled studies showed a statistically and clinically significant long-term benefit of fasting followed by vegetarian diets for RA patients, though more randomized long-term studies are needed for confirmation.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
study_duration: Follow-up data for at least three months after fasting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a mostly raw vegetarian diet could significantly improve fibromyalgia symptoms.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in fibromyalgia symptoms, including reduced pain, enhanced physical performance, and better quality of life, with 19 of 30 subjects classified as responders.
population_specificity: 30 individuals with fibromyalgia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (diet consisted of raw fruits, salads, carrot juice, tubers, grain products, nuts, seeds, and a dehydrated barley grass juice product).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether excluding animal protein (vegetarian diet) could reduce pain and morbidity in fibromyalgia patients by potentially increasing brain tryptophan levels.
results_summary: The vegetarian diet showed a small but significant reduction in pain score, but no significant improvements in fatigue, insomnia, non-restorative sleep, or tender point count. Its effects were much weaker compared to amitriptyline treatment.
population_specificity: 37 subjects with fibromyalgia in the vegetarian diet group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-fat vegetarian diet significantly reduces serum total and LDL cholesterol concentrations in premenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that a low-fat vegetarian diet led to significant reductions in serum LDL (16.9%), HDL (16.5%), and total cholesterol (13.2%) concentrations, while triacylglycerol levels increased by 18.7%. The LDL/HDL ratio remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Premenopausal women aged 22 to 48.
study_duration: 2 menstrual cycles per intervention phase (total of 4 cycles).

study_goal: To determine if a low-fat, vegetarian (vegan) diet improves glycemic and lipid control in patients with non-insulin-dependent diabetes (NIDDM) without exercise or other lifestyle changes.
results_summary: The vegan diet group showed a 28% mean reduction in fasting serum glucose and 7.2 kg weight loss, significantly greater than the control group. Medication use was reduced or discontinued in the vegan group, but HDL levels fell more sharply compared to controls.
population_specificity: Patients with non-insulin-dependent diabetes (NIDDM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare blood pressure, plasma fibrinogen levels, and fibrinolytic activity between nonvegetarians and vegetarians to assess potential cardiovascular benefits of a vegetarian diet.
results_summary: Vegetarians (including semi-vegetarians) showed significantly higher fibrinolytic activity and lower plasma fibrinogen levels compared to nonvegetarians, suggesting potential cardiovascular protection. No significant differences in blood pressure were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Black African Seventh-Day Adventists (students and lecturers) in West Africa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how albumin synthesis rates are affected by diets differing in the proportion of animal versus vegetable protein sources.
results_summary: The study found that albumin synthesis rates (both fractional and absolute) were reduced with a predominantly vegetarian diet (Diet V) compared to an animal protein-rich diet (Diet A). However, supplementing the vegetarian diet with soy protein (Diet VS) prevented this reduction in albumin synthesis.
population_specificity: Healthy male volunteers (n = 4 in Study 1, n = 8 in Study 2).
effective_dosage: Soy protein supplement (18g/d) in Diet VS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a lactoovovegetarian diet on lipid profiles in patients with dyslipoproteinemia types IIa and IIb.
results_summary: The study found that the lactoovovegetarian diet led to decreased levels of cholesterol, atherogenic lipoproteins, and atherogenic coefficient after 24 days of treatment. Patients highly appreciated the diet based on questionnaire responses.
population_specificity: 20 patients with dyslipoproteinemia types IIa and IIb.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a vegetarian diet could reduce Proteus mirabilis and Escherichia coli antibody levels in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and assess its impact on disease activity.
results_summary: The vegetarian diet significantly reduced anti-proteus antibody levels in RA patients, correlating with decreased disease activity, while no significant changes were observed in E. coli antibody levels or in patients on an omnivorous diet.
population_specificity: 53 patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine biochemical and immunological changes in rheumatoid arthritis patients following a fasting and vegetarian diet intervention.
results_summary: The vegetarian diet group showed significant decreases in inflammatory markers (e.g., leukocyte count, IgM RF, complement components) compared to omnivores, suggesting reduced disease activity. Clinical improvement correlated with declines in most laboratory variables, though leukocyte reduction occurred independently of clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid arthritis patients
study_duration: 1 month (with follow-up to 1 year in prior study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fasting followed by a vegetarian diet could influence the growth of Proteus mirabilis and Escherichia coli in urine.
results_summary: The study found that growth of both bacteria in urine samples was significantly slower after 8 days of fasting and a vegan diet, with continued reduction after 18 days, though not significant for E. coli.
population_specificity: 22 patients referred to a health farm for various reasons.
effective_dosage: Fasting for 7-10 days followed by a vegan diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between a vegetarian diet and changes in intestinal flora, and how these changes relate to disease activity in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients.
results_summary: The study found significant alterations in intestinal flora when patients switched from an omnivorous to a vegan diet, with differences also observed between vegan and lactovegetarian diets. Patients with high improvement indices (HI) showed distinct fecal flora compared to those with low improvement indices (LI), suggesting a link between diet, gut microbiota, and RA disease activity.
population_specificity: 53 rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare psychological parameters and clinical outcomes in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients who participated in a clinical trial involving a vegetarian diet versus other RA patients.
results_summary: Patients on a vegetarian diet showed lower psychological distress compared to omnivorous patients, and diet responders had a significantly lower belief in conventional medical treatment than non-responders. The study also found that patients with certain psychological characteristics were more likely to participate in the trial.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients (53 trial participants vs. 71 non-participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a vegetarian diet could serve as an adequate maintenance therapy for Wilson's disease by reducing copper bioavailability.
results_summary: The study found that a vegetarian diet, which reduces copper bioavailability by about 25% or more, may be a viable management tool for Wilson's disease, as observed in two noncompliant patients on lactovegetarian diets. It also highlighted the marginal copper intake in typical American diets, suggesting potential mild copper deficiency risks for some vegetarians.
population_specificity: Wilson's disease patients and individuals on typical American or lactovegetarian diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a vegetarian diet following fasting could improve symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis compared to a conventional diet.
results_summary: The vegetarian diet group showed significant improvements in multiple arthritis-related metrics, including joint tenderness, pain, and inflammation markers, which persisted after one year, while the control group only improved in pain score.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (27 in the diet group, 26 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Initial 7-10 day subtotal fast, followed by a gluten-free vegan diet for 3.5 months, then a lactovegetarian diet for the remainder of the study.
study_duration: 1 year (including initial fasting and dietary phases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the risks of vitamin B12 deficiency in strict vegetarians and the necessity of supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that a strict vegetarian diet without vitamin B12 supplementation led to severe neurologic disturbances in a patient, which resolved completely after B12 treatment. It emphasizes the need for B12 supplementation in strict vegetarians.
population_specificity: 14-year-old white girl on a strictly vegetarian diet (no meat, fish, eggs, or dairy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a vegetarian diet influences blood pressure levels and to identify potential nutrients responsible for these effects.
results_summary: The study found that vegetarian diets, particularly lactoovovegetarian diets, were associated with lower blood pressure and reduced hypertension, independent of obesity or sodium intake. Controlled dietary interventions showed reversible systolic and diastolic blood pressure reductions of 5-6 mm Hg and 2-3 mm Hg, respectively, over 6 weeks.
population_specificity: Seventh-day Adventist vegetarians, Mormon omnivores, healthy normotensive omnivores, and mild hypertensive subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of an ovo-lacto-vegetarian (OLV) diet on blood pressure in mild untreated hypertensive subjects.
results_summary: The study found a significant average reduction in systolic blood pressure (~5 mmHg) associated with the OLV diet, unrelated to changes in urinary sodium, potassium, or body weight but linked to initial blood pressure levels. The diet may have an adjunctive role in managing mild hypertension, though acceptability issues were noted.
population_specificity: Fifty-eight mild untreated hypertensive subjects from the Perth Centre for the 1983 NHF Risk Factor Prevalence Survey.
study_duration: 6 weeks per intervention phase (12-week total trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of an ovo-lacto-vegetarian diet on blood pressure in mild untreated hypertensive subjects.
results_summary: The introduction of an ovo-lacto-vegetarian diet was associated with a significant average reduction in systolic blood pressure of about 5 mmHg, unrelated to changes in urinary sodium, potassium, or body weight. The study concluded that a vegetarian diet may help control mild hypertension but noted challenges with acceptability.
population_specificity: 58 mild untreated hypertensive subjects from the Perth Centre for the 1983 NHF Risk Factor Prevalence Survey.
study_duration: 6 weeks per intervention phase (12-week total trial)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between a vegetarian diet and cardiovascular disease risk factors, comparing vegetarians and omnivores.
results_summary: The study found that vegetarians had significantly lower obesity, blood pressure, serum cholesterol, and improved dietary nutrient profiles compared to omnivores. A controlled dietary intervention showed reductions in blood pressure and cholesterol unrelated to other lifestyle changes.
population_specificity: Seventh-day Adventist vegetarians and Mormon omnivores.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of a vegetarian diet on a child with systemic carnitine deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that adhering to a vegetarian diet increased the frequency and severity of hypoglycaemic episodes in the child, which were resolved with L-carnitine treatment.
population_specificity: A 12-year-old boy with systemic carnitine deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a lacto-ovo vegetarian diet on serum lipid, lipoprotein, and apoprotein levels in adults.
results_summary: The study found that changes in nutrient intake (e.g., increased fiber and polyunsaturated fat, decreased protein) were significantly associated with changes in lipid profiles, including total cholesterol, triglycerides, and HDL subfractions. Principal component analysis identified three dietary factors accounting for 92% of lipid variation.
population_specificity: 19 men and 17 women.
effective_dosage: Not specified (most weekday meals were obtained from a single source).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a vegetarian diet on arthritis and skin diseases, comparing outcomes during a modified fast and a subsequent vegetarian diet period.
results_summary: During fasting, arthralgia improved in many subjects, and some skin conditions (pustulosis palmaris et plantaris and atopic eczema) showed improvement. However, symptoms returned for most patients during the vegetarian diet, except for some psoriasis cases. Serum lactoferrin levels correlated with symptom changes.
population_specificity: Twenty patients with arthritis and various skin diseases.
study_duration: 2-week modified fast followed by 3-week vegetarian diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a vegetarian-based diet improves physical performance in athletes compared to an omnivorous/mixed diet.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in physical performance between vegetarian-based diets and omnivorous/mixed diets. Vegetarian diets neither improved nor hindered athletic performance, but further research is needed due to limited and varied studies.
population_specificity: Athletes and individuals engaging in physical training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare HDL-C levels between lacto-vegetarians and non-vegetarians to assess potential differences in cardiovascular health markers.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in HDL-C levels between lacto-vegetarians and non-vegetarians, suggesting similar cardiovascular lipid profiles. HDL-C levels were unaffected by smoking, alcohol, exercise, or oral contraceptive use.
population_specificity: 306 subjects (182 male, 124 female), including 26 lacto-vegetarians and 280 non-vegetarians (healthy volunteers, factory workers, and patients with minor illnesses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate associations between vegetarian diet and mental disorders, including depressive, anxiety, and somatoform disorders.
results_summary: Vegetarians showed higher prevalence rates of depressive, anxiety, and somatoform disorders compared to non-vegetarians. The study found that adopting a vegetarian diet tended to follow the onset of mental disorders, suggesting no causal role of vegetarian diet in mental disorder etiology.
population_specificity: Representative sample from the German Health Interview and Examination Survey and its Mental Health Supplement (GHS-MHS), including completely vegetarian (N = 54), predominantly vegetarian (N = 190), and non-vegetarian (N = 3872) participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a tri-phasic scaffold loaded with Velvet Antler polypeptides (VAP) in promoting osteochondral defect recovery by supporting osteogenesis and chondrogenic differentiation.
results_summary: The study found that the tri-phasic scaffold with VAP enhanced osteochondral defect recovery in animal models by promoting both osteogenesis and chondrogenic differentiation of fibrocartilage stem cells (FCSCs). In vitro and in vivo results demonstrated significant potential for tissue engineering applications.
population_specificity: Animal models (specific species not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin B-12 supplementation improves arterial endothelial function and reduces intima-media thickness in vegetarians with subnormal vitamin B-12 levels.
results_summary: Vitamin B-12 supplementation significantly improved brachial artery flow-mediated dilation and reduced carotid artery intima-media thickness, with further improvements observed after extended supplementation. No significant changes were noted in blood pressure or lipid profiles.
population_specificity: 50 healthy vegetarians (vegetarian diet for at least 6 years), 44% male, mean age 45±9 years, 70% with subnormal serum B-12 levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of velvet antler polypeptide PNP1 in reducing ischemia reperfusion injury and its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: PNP1 reduced hypoxic cerebral injury in mice, decreased inflammatory factors, promoted angiogenesis, and minimized ischemic penumbra. In vitro, PNP1 protected vascular endothelial cells and suppressed microglial M1 polarization and inflammation.
population_specificity: Mice with induced cerebral ischemia and in vitro vascular endothelial and microglial cell models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether velvet antler water extract (VAWE) could restore the quality of porcine oocytes impaired by LPS-induced oxidative stress.
results_summary: VAWE treatment effectively reversed LPS-induced damage in oocytes, improving meiotic maturation, mitochondrial function, and sperm binding ability by reducing excessive ROS and inhibiting apoptosis.
population_specificity: Porcine oocytes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, effectiveness in reducing heart disease, and special considerations of a vegetarian diet, as well as its association with decreased cardiovascular disease risk.
results_summary: The study found that a carefully planned vegetarian diet with adequate supplementation may be effective for primary prevention of heart disease, is cost-effective, safe, and relatively easy to implement. Improved dietary choices within a vegetarian lifestyle can help manage chronic conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of velvet antler extract (VAE) on preventing osteoporosis and modulating gut microbiota in ovariectomized (OVX) mice.
results_summary: VAE treatment improved bone metabolism markers (serum BGP, Ca2+, CT, HyP), enhanced bone microstructure (BV/TV, Tb.N, Tb.Th, Conn.D), and restored gut microbiota balance by reducing the Firmicutes/Bacteroidetes ratio in OVX mice.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized (OVX) mice as a model for postmenopausal osteoporosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a hydrogel containing velvet antler blood peptides (CAVBPH) could effectively promote wound healing in diabetic ulcers by regulating angiogenesis, inflammation, and skin flora.
results_summary: The study found that CAVBPH significantly promoted wound healing in diabetic mice by enhancing cell proliferation, angiogenesis, and reducing inflammation, likely through activation of the PI3K/AKT/mTOR/HIF-1α/VEGFA pathway and modulation of skin microbiota.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic mice with induced skin wounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of a chitosan/sodium alginate/velvet antler blood peptides (VBPs) hydrogel (CAVBPH) to promote skin wound healing and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: CAVBPH demonstrated desirable characteristics such as thermo-sensitivity, antioxidation, antibacterial activity, and biosafety, significantly accelerating wound healing in mice by enhancing cell proliferation, angiogenesis, ECM secretion, and reducing inflammation. The efficacy was linked to activation of the PI3K/AKT/mTOR and SIRT1/NF-κB pathways.
population_specificity: Mice with skin wounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enzymatically digested velvet antler peptides (EVAP) could promote regenerative wound healing by reducing scar formation and improving healing quality.
results_summary: EVAP significantly accelerated wound healing, reduced scar formation, improved tissue quality (angiogenesis, skin appendages, collagen distribution), and modulated gene expression to favor anti-scarring effects, likely by inhibiting the TGF-β signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Rats (in vivo) and human dermal fibroblasts (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Chinese herbal prescriptions containing Velvet Antler (VA) or Ejiao in treating uterine fibroids.
results_summary: The study found that TCM (E/VA) combined with mifepristone reduced uterine fibroid volume more effectively than mifepristone alone, improved fibroid-related symptoms, and lowered estradiol and progesterone levels in non-menopausal women, with fewer adverse events compared to controls.
population_specificity: 844 patients with uterine fibroids, including non-menopausal women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active ingredients and molecular targets of velvet antler in treating postmenopausal osteoporosis (PMOP) and explore its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study identified key components (17β-E2, adenosine triphosphate, oestrone) and target genes (AKT1, IL6, MAPK3, TP53, EGFR, SRC, TNF) involved in regulating PI3K/Akt and MAPK signaling pathways, which influence cellular processes like differentiation, apoptosis, and inflammation to treat PMOP. H&E staining and micro-CT confirmed trabecular bone tissue improvements.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal osteoporosis (PMOP) patients (implied, not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Velvet Antler's effect on heart failure caused by ischemia-reperfusion and explore its mechanism via SERCA2a regulation.
results_summary: Velvet Antler improved cardiac function, reduced myocardial fibrosis, and restored SERCA2a and PKA activity in rats with heart failure, outperforming enalapril in some measures.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with induced heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether antler extract (AE) inhibits prostate cancer growth in a xenograft model and explore its underlying mechanism.
results_summary: AE significantly reduced tumor growth by 65.08%, lowered PSA and DHT levels, and increased testosterone. It also downregulated angiogenesis and EMT-related genes while upregulating TIMP-1, TIMP-2, and E-cadherin.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer xenograft model (animal study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Velvet Antler water extracts (SVAE and RVAE) on intestinal barrier function and inflammation in an in vitro model of colitis.
results_summary: Both SVAE and RVAE improved intestinal barrier integrity by reducing permeability and enhancing tight junction protein expression (occludin and ZO-1). RVAE increased tight junction proteins, while SVAE reduced MLCK activity, and both extracts promoted CCL20 production without cytotoxicity.
population_specificity: Human colonic epithelial cells (Caco-2) in an in vitro DSS-induced colitis model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Velvet Antler Polypeptide (VAP) could modulate the Wnt/β-catenin signaling pathway to treat facet joint osteoarthritis (FJ-OA) in a mouse model.
results_summary: VAP partially reversed osteophyte formation, improved cartilage tissue invasion, increased total cartilage area, reduced β-catenin levels, upregulated collagen II, and downregulated ECM degradation enzymes (MMP13, ADAMTS4, ADAMTS5).
population_specificity: β-catenin conditional activation mice (cartilage-specific overexpression) and Cre-negative littermate controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of aqueous velvet antler extract (AVA) in mouse models of LPS-induced acute lung injury (ALI).
results_summary: AVA inhibited inflammatory markers (NO, TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6, IL-10), reduced lung inflammation, enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity, and blocked key inflammatory pathways (MAPK/NF-κB) while activating protective pathways (AMPK/Nrf2).
population_specificity: Mouse models of LPS-induced acute lung injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Velvet Antler proteins (VA-pro) influence endothelial progenitor cell (EPC) viability and the potential molecular mechanisms involved.
results_summary: VA-pro promoted EPC proliferation and migration, particularly at 1 mg/ml, and increased activation of Notch1 intracellular domain, Hes1, phosphorylated-Akt, and phosphorylated-mTOR, suggesting regulation via Notch and Akt signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Endothelial progenitor cells (EPCs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different sections of velvet antler (upper, middle, basal) in promoting longitudinal bone growth in growing rats and assess osteogenic activity in vitro.
results_summary: Velvet antler promoted longitudinal bone growth and growth plate height in adolescent rats, increased BMP-2 expression, and enhanced osteogenic activity in MG-63 cells, with effects strongest in the upper section and decreasing toward the basal section.
population_specificity: Adolescent rats and osteoblastic MG-63 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-obesity effects of an enzymatic hydrolysate of velvet antler (VAPH) in inhibiting adipogenesis in 3T3-L1 cells and in high-fat diet-fed obese mice.
results_summary: VAPH demonstrated dose-dependent inhibition of adipogenesis by reducing triglyceride accumulation and down-regulating adipogenesis-related proteins. In obese mice, VAPH significantly reduced body weight gain, lowered serum glucose and triglyceride levels, increased HDL-C, and reduced hepatic lipid accumulation and adipocyte size.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 cells and high-fat diet-fed obese mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanism of Velvet Antler proteins (VA-pro) on cardiac microvascular endothelial cells (CMECs) subjected to ischemia-hypoxia (IH) to understand its potential in treating ischemic heart disease.
results_summary: VA-pro improved CMEC viability, proliferation, migration, tubule formation, and mitochondrial membrane potential while reducing apoptosis under IH conditions, with 1 mg/ml VA-pro showing the most significant effects. The study suggests VA-pro works via the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Primary cardiac microvascular endothelial cells (CMECs) in vitro.
study_duration: 46 hours of ischemia-hypoxia exposure followed by VA-pro treatment (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-inflammatory effects of velvet antler Alcalase hydrolysate (VAAH) in vitro and in zebrafish, and assess its potential as a natural remedy.
results_summary: VAAH significantly inhibited nitric oxide (NO) production and reduced inflammatory mediators (iNOS, COX-2) in LPS-induced cells. It also decreased cell death, NO, and ROS levels in LPS-stimulated zebrafish, suggesting strong anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: In vitro cell lines and LPS-stimulated zebrafish.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sVAP32, a peptide from velvet antler, could prevent cardiac fibrosis by blocking TGF-β1 signaling in a pressure overload model.
results_summary: sVAP32 improved cardiac dysfunction, reduced fibrosis, and inhibited TGF-β1 downstream signaling in rats subjected to transverse aortic constriction. It also blocked similar fibrotic effects in cultured cardiac fibroblasts by disrupting TGF-β1 receptor binding.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats and cultured cardiac fibroblasts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the regenerative properties of velvet antler and its potential applications in biomedical fields such as regenerative medicine and trauma treatment.
results_summary: The study identified active proteins and peptides in velvet antler and explored their differentiation across growth periods, linking proteome differences to the antler's life cycle. The findings suggest potential applications in regenerative medicine, anti-inflammatory treatment, and growth factor research.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on antler biology rather than human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Siberian Stag velvet antler extract baths, combined with exercise therapy and massage, in treating arterial hypertension and chronic psychoemotional overtension.
results_summary: The study found that velvet antler extract baths improved homeostatic parameters, enhanced working capacity, promoted psychological stability, and increased adaptive potential in patients with arterial hypertension and chronic psychoemotional overtension.
population_specificity: 35 patients with arterial hypertension and concomitant chronic psychoemotional overtension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-osteoporotic effects of different sections (upper, middle, basal) of velvet antler in ovariectomized rats.
results_summary: The upper and middle sections of velvet antler showed higher levels of bioactive constituents (e.g., testosterone, IGF-1) and significantly improved bone strength and microarchitecture compared to the basal section. VAU and VAM also dose-dependently enhanced cell proliferation and mineralization in MC3T3-E1 cells.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized rats (a model for postmenopausal osteoporosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antiallergic effects of Velvet Antler (VA) from Formosan sambar deer in mouse models of asthma and allergic responses.
results_summary: VA powder reduced total and OVA-specific IgE levels, increased Th1, Treg, and Th17 cytokines, inhibited Th2 and proinflammatory cytokines, and alleviated airway inflammation and hyperresponsiveness in allergic asthma mice.
population_specificity: OVA-sensitized and OVA-allergic asthma mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of Velvet Antler on cardiac function in rats with heart failure following myocardial infarction, testing its potential as an alternative treatment.
results_summary: Velvet Antler partially reversed changes in cardiac functional parameters and serum BNP levels in rats with heart failure, suggesting it may be a complementary treatment for heart failure.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with heart failure induced by left coronary artery ligation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-osteoporotic effects of total velvet antler polypeptides (TVAPL) in ovariectomized rats and explore their mechanism of action.
results_summary: TVAPL significantly reversed osteoporosis in ovariectomized rats by improving bone weight coefficient, bone mineral density, and bone microarchitecture. It also inhibited IL-1 and IL-6 activation and promoted cartilage and osteoblast-like cell proliferation.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized Wistar rats (postmenopausal osteoporosis model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-osteoporotic effects of the combination therapy of velvet antler middle sections (VAMs) and velvet antler blood (VAM-B) and provide scientific evidence supporting the traditional preference for redder antler.
results_summary: VAM-B treatment in ovariectomized rats reduced body weight by 10.7%, increased vertebral and femur strength by 18.1% and 15.4%, respectively, and improved tibial trabecular bone microarchitecture. Alkaline phosphatase levels decreased significantly, but estradiol levels remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized (OVX) rats

study_goal: To study the effects of velvet antler polypeptides (VAPs) on osteoarthritic chondrocytes in rabbits, focusing on cell proliferation, apoptosis, and extracellular matrix metabolism.
results_summary: VAPs did not affect cell proliferation or the cell cycle but reduced early apoptosis, inhibited collagen I and X mRNA expression, and increased glycosaminoglycan and collagen type II levels. They also modulated MMP expression, maintaining cartilage matrix balance.
population_specificity: Osteoarthritic rabbits

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-infective activity of Velvet Antler (VA) and its extracts against pathogenic Staphylococcus aureus in vitro and in vivo, focusing on immune modulation and inflammatory response suppression.
results_summary: VA extracts stimulated immune cell proliferation and suppressed proinflammatory cytokines in vitro, while in vivo tests showed reduced bacterial load in S. aureus-infected mice and enhanced macrophage phagocytic activity. The protective mechanisms of VA included immune enhancement and inflammatory cytokine suppression.
population_specificity: S. aureus-infected mice (in vivo) and immune cells (in vitro)
effective_dosage: Up to 150 μg mL(-1) in vitro (dose-dependent)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of velvet antler extract (VAE) on extracellular matrix (ECM) production in human dermal fibroblasts cultured in vitro.
results_summary: VAE accelerated fibroblast growth in a dose-dependent manner, increased production of ECM components (type 1 collagen, fibronectin, elastin), and enhanced cell migration. The study also identified up-regulation of genes related to connective tissue integrity.
population_specificity: Primary cultured human dermal fibroblasts

study_goal: To investigate the protective effect of antler polypeptide on motor function recovery and pathological changes in rats with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: Antler polypeptide improved motor activity and reduced tissue edema and inflammatory infiltration in SCI rats, with effects being dose-dependent and most pronounced at 15 mg.
population_specificity: Rats with induced spinal cord injury.
effective_dosage: Different doses, with 15 mg being notably effective.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cardioprotective effects of Velvet Antler peptides (VAP) on acute ischemic myocardial injury in rats and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: VAP significantly reduced infarct size, ST elevation, and levels of CK, LDH, AST, and MDA while increasing SOD activity in serum and myocardial tissue, suggesting antioxidant and anti-lipid peroxidation properties.
population_specificity: Rats with induced myocardial ischemia injury.
effective_dosage: 30, 60, and 120 mg/kg, administered via tail vein injection at 12 and 23 hours post-LAD occlusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether copper supplementation in red deer stags improved velvet antler weight, grade, financial value, and liveweight gain.
results_summary: Copper supplementation did not significantly affect velvet antler weight, growth rate, grade, value, or stag liveweight gain, but it increased serum ferroxidase concentrations and liver copper levels.
population_specificity: Rising 2-year-old red deer stags on a commercial deer farm in Hawke's Bay.
effective_dosage: 20 g boluses of copper-oxide wire particles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether elk velvet antler could effectively manage residual symptoms (joint pain, swelling, functional ability, etc.) in patients with stage 2 to 3 rheumatoid arthritis who had not fully responded to standard treatment.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the velvet antler and placebo groups on any measured outcomes, including joint pain, swelling, functional ability, or quality of life. Although some patients reported subjective improvements, these were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients (N=168) with stage 2 to 3 rheumatoid arthritis experiencing residual symptoms after standard treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different routes and doses of local anesthetic for providing analgesia during velvet antler removal in adult stags.
results_summary: The High-dose ring-block provided the most effective and rapid analgesia, with 24/25 antlers removed without response by 2 minutes. The High-site nerve-block also showed better efficacy than the Low-site nerve-block, though some stags required additional anesthetic after 4 minutes.
population_specificity: Adult red deer stags (≥2-years-old).
effective_dosage: High-dose ring-block (1 ml/cm pedicle circumference), Low-dose ring-block (0.4 ml/cm pedicle circumference), High-site and Low-site regional nerve blocks (5 ml per site).
study_duration: Immediate effects assessed within 4 minutes post-injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different routes and doses of local anesthetic for providing analgesia during velvet antler procedures in young stags.
results_summary: Ring blocks provided more consistent analgesia than regional nerve blocks, with the high-dose ring block being the fastest and most effective. Regional nerve blocks were more effective when combined with auriculopalpebral nerve anesthesia.
population_specificity: 1-year-old male red and red X wapiti deer with velvet antler lengths of 10-30 cm.
effective_dosage: 2% lignocaine HCL at doses of 5, 10, or 15 ml per pedicle for ring blocks; 5 ml per site for regional blocks.
study_duration: Immediate effects measured at 1, 2, 4, and 8 minutes post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of quality elk velvet antler (QEVA) in alleviating osteoarthrosis symptoms in dogs through gait analysis, clinical assessments, and owner-reported vitality.
